elements.content: Solvothermal reaction of 5,10,10-trimethyl-bicyclo[2.2.1]-heptano-2-phenyl imidazole (TBHPI-H) with CuBr as a catalyst gave a one-dimensional infinite chain metal organic framework (MOF) (1) with the formulation {[(cis-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI)2(trans-(2C-2C)Bi-TPHPI)](Cu2Br2)(Cu4Br4)} n . The (2C-2C)bi-TPHPI ligand formed in situ was shown to be present as both the cis and trans C(2)−C(2) coupling isomers, which was confirmed by LC-MS analysis revealing two peaks at 19.96 and 21.65 min containing a peak at 503 Da assignable to the [M + H]+ molecular ion fragment. To our knowledge, the trapping and structural characterization of such intermediates through formation of MOF complexes is unprecedented.
elements.clean_text: Solvothermal reaction of 5,10,10-trimethyl-bicyclo[2.2.1]-heptano-2-phenyl imidazole (TBHPI-H) with CuBr as a catalyst gave a one-dimensional infinite chain metal organic framework (MOF) (1) with the formulation {[(cis-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI)2(trans-(2C-2C)Bi-TPHPI)](Cu2Br2)(Cu4Br4)} n . The (2C-2C)bi-TPHPI ligand formed in situ was shown to be present as both the cis and trans C(2)-C(2) coupling isomers, which was confirmed by LC-MS analysis revealing two peaks at 19.96 and 21.65 min containing a peak at 503 Da assignable to the [M + H]+ molecular ion fragment. To our knowledge, the trapping and structural characterization of such intermediates through formation of MOF complexes is unprecedented.

elements.content: Solvothermal reaction of 5,10,10-trimethyl-bicyclo[2.2.1]-heptano-2-phenyl imidazole (TBI-H) with CuBr as catalyst gave one-dimensional infinite chain metal organic framework (MOF) (1) with the formulation {[(cis-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI)2(trans-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI)](Cu2Br2)(Cu4Br4)} n . The (2C-2C)bi-TPHPI ligand formed in situ was shown to be present as both the cis and trans C(2)−C(2) coupling isomers, which was confirmed by LC-MS analysis revealing two peaks at 19.96 and 21.65 min containing a peak at 503 Da assignable to the [M + H]+ molecular ion fragment. To our knowledge, the trapping and structural characterization of such intermediates through formation of MOF complexes is unprecedented.

The (2C-2C)bi-TPHPI ligand formed in situ was shown to be present as both the cis and trans C(2)-C(2) coupling isomers, which was confirmed by LC-MS analysis revealing two peaks at 19.96 and 21.65 min containing a peak at 503 Da assignable to the [M + H]+ molecular ion fragment. To our knowledge, the trapping and structural characterization of such intermediates through formation of MOF complexes is unprecedented.

elements.content: The isolation and characterization of intermediates formed during bond formation and dissociation is an important strategy to deciphering the mechanism of chemical reactions and biological processes. A model system for such studies that has attracted much attention in recent years is the K3[Fe(CN)6]-mediated oxidative dimerization of 2,4,5-triphenyl-1H-imidazole (THI) and its derivatives. In these studies, the reaction was reported to proceed to give the C(2)−N(1) adduct 2,4,5-triphenyl-1-(2,4,5-triphenyl-2H-imidazol-2-yl)-1H-imidazole [(1N-2C)bim] as the sole product (Scheme ). The C(2)−C(2) adduct 2,4,5-triphenyl-2-(2,4,5-triphenyl-2H-imidazol-2-yl)-2H-imidazole [(2C-2C)bim] was only obtained in 14% yield upon photodissociation of (1N-2C)bim, which was presumed to be due to dimerization of the radical species following second-order kinetics and an increase in the radical species population leading to formation of (2C-2C)bim in a nonlinear manner. However, direct observation or isolation of a (2C-2C)bim-type product in monomeric metal-catalyzed radical-couplings has remained a challenge, which is surprising in view of the fact that copper(I) bromide-catalyzed cross-dehydrogenative couplings as strategies for carbon−carbon bond formation is of immense current interest. In the course of our investigations on solvothermal reactions of 5,10,10-trimethyl-bicyclo[2.2.1]-heptano-2-phenyl imidazole (TBHPI-H) with CuBr, we report herein the synthesis and crystal structure of TBHPI-H, and trapping of the intermediate during cross-coupling of TBHPI-H in which dimerization was shown by X-ray crystallography to occur between the C(2) center of one TBHPI-H molecule and with the C(2) center of another TBHPI-H molecule, and preliminary studies on the permittivity properties of these intermediates (Scheme ). The notable features of this intermolecular C−C bond formation process are (1) formation of only the (2C-2C)bim-type product and (2) rehybridization of the carbon centers involved in the bond formation process from sp2 to sp3, which, to our knowledge, is unprecedented for such transformations.
elements.clean_text: The isolation and characterization of intermediates formed during bond formation and dissociation is an important strategy to deciphering the mechanism of chemical reactions and biological processes. A model system for such studies that has attracted much attention in recent years is the K3[Fe(CN)6]-mediated oxidative dimerization of 2,4,5-triphenyl-1H-imidazole (THI) and its derivatives. In these studies, the reaction was reported to proceed to give the C(2)-N(1) adduct 2,4,5-triphenyl-1-(2,4,5-triphenyl-2H-imidazol-2-yl)-1H-imidazole [(1N-2C)bim] as the sole product (Scheme ). The C(2)-C(2) adduct 2,4,5-triphenyl-2-(2,4,5-triphenyl-2H-imidazol-2-yl)-2H-imidazole [(2C-2C)bim] was only obtained in 14% yield upon photodissociation of (1N-2C)bim, which was presumed to be due to dimerization of the radical species following second-order kinetics and an increase in the radical species population leading to formation of (2C-2C)bim in a nonlinear manner. However, direct observation or isolation of a (2C-2C)bim-type product in monomeric metal-catalyzed radical-couplings has remained a challenge, which is surprising in view of the fact that copper(I) bromide-catalyzed cross-dehydrogenative couplings as strategies for carbon-carbon bond formation is of immense current interest. In the course of our investigations on solvothermal reactions of 5,10,10-trimethyl-bicyclo[2.2.1]-heptano-2-phenyl imidazole (TBHPI-H) with CuBr, we report herein the synthesis and crystal structure of TBHPI-H, and trapping of the intermediate during cross-coupling of TBHPI-H in which dimerization was shown by X-ray crystallography to occur between the C(2) center of one TBHPI-H molecule and with the C(2) center of another TBHPI-H molecule, and preliminary studies on the permittivity properties of these intermediates (Scheme ). The notable features of this intermolecular C-C bond formation process are (1) formation of only the (2C-2C)bim-type product and (2) rehybridization of the carbon centers involved in the bond formation process from sp2 to sp3, which, to our knowledge, is unprecedented for such transformations.

TBHPI-H was prepared by the reaction of 1,7,7-trimethylbicyclo[2.2.1]-heptane-2,3-dione with benzaldehyde and NH4OAc. As depicted in Figure , the structure of TBHPI-H was confirmed by X-ray crystallography, which also revealed that the imidazole and phenyl rings are almost coplanar with a dihedral of 2°.
elements.clean_text: TBHPI-H was prepared by the reaction of 1,7,7-trimethylbicyclo[2.2.1]-heptane-2,3-dione with benzaldehyde and NH4OAc. As depicted in Figure , the structure of TBHPI-H was confirmed by X-ray crystallography, which also revealed that the imidazole and phenyl rings are almost coplanar with a dihedral of 2°.

elements.content: ORTEP of TBHPI-H depicted with ellipsoid probability 25%.
elements.clean_text: 1  ORTEP of TBHPI-H depicted with ellipsoid probability 25%.

elements.content: Solvothermal reaction of TBHPI-H with CuBr at 70 °C afforded metal organic framework (MOF) 1 as yellow-pale block crystals. As depicted in Figure , X-ray crystal structure determination reveals that the dimerization only takes place at the C(2) centers of two TBHPI-H molecules. In addition, both the cis and trans isomers of TBHPI-H were obtained and that 1 is thus comprised of both cis- and trans-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI and can be formulated as {[(cis-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI)2(trans-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI)](Cu2Br2)(Cu4Br4)2(H2O)} n with a cis to trans TBHPI-H ligand ratio of 2. Formation of cis-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI is thought to occur via overlapping of TBHPI-H radicals that do not undergo rotation prior dimerization, while the trans adduct was reasoned to be formed by one of the TBHPI-H radicals undergoing a 180° rotation prior to dimerization (see ). In this work, the cis-isomer refers to the two methyl groups sitting on the same side to each other in TBHPI-H, whereas trans-isomers they sit on opposite sides to each other. Another pale-yellow Cu+ complex coexists in the mixture of MOF 1, suggesting that it coordinated to only the cis-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI ligands. This suggests that the overall cis to trans ligand ratio is 3, which is supported by LC-MS analysis of all powdered samples (see ). The in situ formed cis-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI acts as tetradentate linker that connects four Cu centers to give rise to the formation of a Cu2Br2 dimer in which each Cu center displays a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry composed of two N atoms from two imidazole rings and two Br atoms. At the other end of the same imidazole ring, the cis-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI connects four Cu centers together from two Cu4Br4 clusters. In addition, the in situ formed trans-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI ligand acts as a tetradentate spacer that links four Cu centers together from two Cu4Br4 clusters. In this latter case, one of the Cu centers sits in a tetrahedral coordination geometry, while other three Cu centers are found to sit in a trigonal coordination environment. Cu−Cu (from weak to strong) interactions are observed between adjacent two Cu atoms with Cu−Cu distances of 2.620 (strong interactions) to 2.915 Å. Thus, as shown in Figure c, the one-dimensional (1D) chain is repeated by one trans-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI ligand, two cis-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI ligands, a Cu2Br2 dimer and a Cu4Br4 cluster. It is worth noting that the unique Cu4Br4 cluster contains only one μ3-Br atom even though such a cluster has been previously reported by Kursheva et al. to involve two μ3-Br atoms (Figure d).
elements.clean_text: Solvothermal reaction of TBHPI-H with CuBr at 70 °C afforded metal organic framework (MOF) 1 as yellow-pale block crystals. As depicted in Figure , X-ray crystal structure determination reveals that the dimerization only takes place at the C(2) centers of two TBHPI-H molecules. In addition, both the cis and trans isomers of TBHPI-H were obtained and that 1 is thus comprised of both cis- and trans-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI and can be formulated as {[(cis-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI)2(trans-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI)](Cu2Br2)(Cu4Br4)2(H2O)} n  with a cis to trans TBHPI-H ligand ratio of 2. Formation of cis-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI is thought to occur via overlapping of TBHPI-H radicals that do not undergo rotation prior dimerization, while the trans adduct was reasoned to be formed by one of the TBHPI-H radicals undergoing a 180° rotation prior to dimerization (see ). In this work, the cis-isomer refers to the two methyl groups sitting on the same side to each other in TBHPI-H, whereas trans-isomers they sit on opposite sides to each other. Another pale-yellow Cu+ complex coexists in the mixture of MOF 1, suggesting that it coordinated to only the cis-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI ligands. This suggests that the overall cis to trans ligand ratio is 3, which is supported by LC-MS analysis of all powdered samples (see ). The in situ formed cis-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI acts as tetradentate linker that connects four Cu centers to give rise to the formation of a Cu2Br2 dimer in which each Cu center displays a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry composed of two N atoms from two imidazole rings and two Br atoms. At the other end of the same imidazole ring, the cis-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI connects four Cu centers together from two Cu4Br4 clusters. In addition, the in situ formed trans-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI ligand acts as a tetradentate spacer that links four Cu centers together from two Cu4Br4 clusters. In this latter case, one of the Cu centers sits in a tetrahedral coordination geometry, while other three Cu centers are found to sit in a trigonal coordination environment. Cu-Cu (from weak to strong) interactions are observed between adjacent two Cu atoms with Cu-Cu distances of 2.620 (strong interactions) to 2.915 Å. Thus, as shown in Figure c, the one-dimensional (1D) chain is repeated by one trans-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI ligand, two cis-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI ligands, a Cu2Br2 dimer and a Cu4Br4 cluster. It is worth noting that the unique Cu4Br4 cluster contains only one μ3-Br atom even though such a cluster has been previously reported by Kursheva et al. to involve two μ3-Br atoms (Figure d).

elements.content: Perspective views of (a) trans-trans-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI; (b) cis-trans-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI; (c) 1D-chain representation of 1 composed of two cis-ligands, one trans-ligand, one Cu2Br2 dimer, and two Cu4Br4 clusters; water molecule and H atom omitted for clarity. (d) Cu4Br4 cluster with μ3-Br bridging ligand; and (e) Cu2Br2 dimer.
elements.clean_text: 2  Perspective views of (a) trans-trans-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI; (b) cis-trans-(2C-2C)bi-TPHPI; (c) 1D-chain representation of 1 composed of two cis-ligands, one trans-ligand, one Cu2Br2 dimer, and two Cu4Br4 clusters; water molecule and H atom omitted for clarity. (d) Cu4Br4 cluster with μ3-Br bridging ligand; and (e) Cu2Br2 dimer.

elements.content: As detailed in the , decomposition of 1 was carried out using ammonia solution and extracted with chloroform. Mass spectrometric analysis of the resulting solution revealed that a peak at 503 that could be assigned to the [M + H+] molecular ion fragment, supported the in situ formation of the (2C-2C)bi-TPHPI ligand. Detection of two peaks at 503 by LC-MS analysis showed that two types of (2C-2C)bi-TPHPI ligands are present in 1, which is consistent with X-ray structural analysis mentioned earlier.
elements.clean_text: As detailed in the , decomposition of 1 was carried out using ammonia solution and extracted with chloroform. Mass spectrometric analysis of the resulting solution revealed that a peak at 503 that could be assigned to the [M + H+] molecular ion fragment, supported the in situ formation of the (2C-2C)bi-TPHPI ligand. Detection of two peaks at 503 by LC-MS analysis showed that two types of (2C-2C)bi-TPHPI ligands are present in 1, which is consistent with X-ray structural analysis mentioned earlier.

elements.content: In this work, we have also examined the reactions of 5,10,10-trimethyl-bicyclo[2.2.1]-heptano-2-(3′-pyridyl or 4′-methyl-phenyl)imidazole (TBH-3-P or TBH-4-MP) with CuBr under similar conditions. Our findings reveal that C−C coupling can be readily achieved at relative low temperatures (70 °C) and (2C-2C)biTBH-4-MP and (2C-2C)biTBH-3-P can be furnished with yields in excess of 70% (see ). This is in contrast to K3[Fe(CN)6]-mediated dimerization of TBHPI-H and its derivatives, which were found to give neither the (1N-2C)bim- nor (2C-2C)bim-type products. Similarly, neither the (1N-2C)bim- nor the (2C-2C)bim-type product was obtained from reactions of 2−3′-nitro-phenyl-4,5-biphenyl-1H-imidazole (THI) and its derivatives and CuBr catalyst (see ). In this latter case, one possible reason could be due to the presence of a large conjugation effect since the imidazole ring contains π-conjugated phenyl groups at C(4) and C(5).
elements.clean_text: In this work, we have also examined the reactions of 5,10,10-trimethyl-bicyclo[2.2.1]-heptano-2-(3'-pyridyl or 4'-methyl-phenyl)imidazole (TBH-3-P or TBH-4-MP) with CuBr under similar conditions. Our findings reveal that C-C coupling can be readily achieved at relative low temperatures (70 °C) and (2C-2C)biTBH-4-MP and (2C-2C)biTBH-3-P can be furnished with yields in excess of 70% (see ). This is in contrast to K3[Fe(CN)6]-mediated dimerization of TBHPI-H and its derivatives, which were found to give neither the (1N-2C)bim- nor (2C-2C)bim-type products. Similarly, neither the (1N-2C)bim- nor the (2C-2C)bim-type product was obtained from reactions of 2-3'-nitro-phenyl-4,5-biphenyl-1H-imidazole (THI) and its derivatives and CuBr catalyst (see ). In this latter case, one possible reason could be due to the presence of a large conjugation effect since the imidazole ring contains π-conjugated phenyl groups at C(4) and C(5).

elements.content: Our preliminary studies on the dielectric properties of 1 reveal that it exhibits a relatively high static dielectric constant at room temperature. As shown in Figure , extrapolation of a plot of permittivity vs frequency gives an estimated dielectric constant of ca. 18, with the real part of the dielectric constant smoothly increasing with decreasing frequency.
elements.clean_text: Our preliminary studies on the dielectric properties of 1 reveal that it exhibits a relatively high static dielectric constant at room temperature. As shown in Figure , extrapolation of a plot of permittivity vs frequency gives an estimated dielectric constant of ca. 18, with the real part of the dielectric constant smoothly increasing with decreasing frequency.

elements.content: Frequency dependence of dielectric constant of 1 at room temperature where ε = ε′ − iε′′ (ε′ and ε′′ are the respective real and imaginary parts of permittivity; dielectric loss tan δ = ε′′/ε′ remains unchanged).
elements.clean_text: 3  Frequency dependence of dielectric constant of 1 at room temperature where ε = ε' - iε'' (ε' and ε'' are the respective real and imaginary parts of permittivity; dielectric loss tan δ = ε''/ε' remains unchanged).

elements.content: In this work, we have developed a new C−C bond formation strategy for in situ construction of functionalized MOFs. Efforts are currently underway to explore the scope of this new synthetic route to functionalized MOFs with useful physical properties and results will be reported in due course.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we have developed a new C-C bond formation strategy for in situ construction of functionalized MOFs. Efforts are currently underway to explore the scope of this new synthetic route to functionalized MOFs with useful physical properties and results will be reported in due course.

elements.content: Detailed experimental procedures, IR spectroscopic data, additional ORTEP views, and X-ray crystallographic cif files. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

metadata.title: Copper(I) Bromide-Mediated Coupling of Imidazoles. Trapping and X-Ray Crystal Structures of the Reaction Intermediates
